ThingDef.label: AnyPlant Pot
ThingDef.description: A specially engineered planter with an adjustable reservoir for excess water. This prevents overwatering, and with the correct settings, this pot can support the growth of nearly any plant. It's rather expensive to build, but if you can dream it, this can grow it, provided the light levels and temperature are correct.

ThingDef.label: hydrangea (pink)
ThingDef.description: A unique and beautiful flowering shrub. The color of its flowers is affected by the pH of the soil it's planted in. Hydrangeas turn pink when planted in a more alkaline soil.

ThingDef.label: hydrangea (blue)
ThingDef.description: A unique and beautiful flowering shrub. The color of its flowers is affected by the pH of the soil it's planted in. Hydrangeas turn blue when planted in a more acidic soil.

ThingDef.label: hydrangea (purple)
ThingDef.description: A unique and beautiful flowering shrub. The color of its flowers is affected by the pH of the soil it's planted in. Hydrangeas turn purple when planted in a soil that's only slightly acidic.

ThingDef.label: rice plant
ThingDef.description: A short, fast-growing crop that yields small edible grains. Its great nutritional ouput and ease of cultivation has made it the economic core of many great civilizations. While rice grows quickly, it is sensitive to soil fertility and will not fare well in poor soil.

ThingDef.label: potato plant
ThingDef.description: A highly nutritious tuber. Potatoes grow well even in somewhat poor soil, and form a delicious crispy outer coating when fried in oil.

ThingDef.label: corn plant
ThingDef.description: A tall grain plant which produces ears of soft, edible seeds. While corn takes a long time to grow, it yields lots of food compared to other crops. Harvested corn takes a long time to spoil.

ThingDef.label: strawberry plant
ThingDef.description: A low bush-like plant that yields fragile but delicious strawberries. While it isn't quite as productive calorie-for-calorie as other crops, strawberries are delicious even when raw.

ThingDef.label: haygrass
ThingDef.description: A mixture of nutrient-rich grasses which yield large amounts of hay. Hay is edible for animals, but not humans.

ThingDef.label: cotton plant
ThingDef.description: A mid-size crop that yields fine white cotton fibers. These are used to make cloth.

ThingDef.label: devilstrand
ThingDef.description: This fragile mushroom was genetically engineered to produce a silk net that is both difficult to tear and soft to the touch. While the mushroom takes a very long time to grow, only exotic ultra-tech fabrics outperform its devilstrand fibers.\n\nSome say it's called devilstrand because of its red color. Others think it owes its name to the greed it inspires in people.

ThingDef.label: healroot
ThingDef.description: A slow-growing plant which yields herbal medicine when harvested. Sowing and harvesting healroot are both very labor-intensive tasks because of its delicate shoots.\n\nHealroot was selectively bred for centuries by settlers. It is sometimes also called "healer's hand" by tribespeople - a nickname it owes to its five major medicinal virtues.

ThingDef.label: hop plant
ThingDef.description: A flowering crop that yields hops, an essential ingredient in beer.

ThingDef.label: smokeleaf plant
ThingDef.description: A leafy crop grown for the psychological effects of chemicals in its leaves. Smokeleaf leaves can be prepared into joints at the crafting spot. Smokeleaf makes a user feel relaxed, but reduces motivation, and can be addictive.

ThingDef.label: psychoid plant
ThingDef.description: A leafy plant which generates the chemical compound psychite. Originally evolved as a defense mechanism to ward off plant-eating animals by overstimulating and sickening them, the psychite drug can be extracted and refined into various forms for recreational use. It is addictive.

ThingDef.label: grass
ThingDef.description: Wild grass. Grows anywhere there is a little light and minimally fertile ground.

ThingDef.label: rose
ThingDef.description: A beautiful cultivated flower, the rose has been a symbol of love since Earth's ancient era.

ThingDef.label: rose
ThingDef.description: A beautiful cultivated flower, the rose has been a symbol of love since Earth's ancient era.

ThingDef.label: daylily
ThingDef.description: A cultivated flower with wide petals and a short lifespan. Daylilies are very beautiful, but must be replanted often.

ThingDef.label: bush
ThingDef.description: A short shrub. Does not typically talk.

ThingDef.label: brambles
ThingDef.description: Tangled, thorny, woody shoots covered with leaves. Brambles grow in clusters, and slow down anyone moving over them.

ThingDef.label: dandelions
ThingDef.description: A tiny yellow flower which grows in large clusters. Though it is often considered a weed, dandelions in bloom are quite beautiful.

ThingDef.label: astragalus
ThingDef.description: A small perennial wildflower that grows in alpine climates.

ThingDef.label: moss
ThingDef.description: Wild moss that grows in clumps in areas of low light and cool temperatures. Moss takes a long time to grow, but is very frost-resistant.

ThingDef.label: berry bush
ThingDef.description: A bushy wild plant which yields delicious berries. Berries can be cooked, but they're also good to eat even when raw.

ThingDef.label: agave
ThingDef.description: A large-leafed desert plant with edible flowers and stalks.

ThingDef.label: pincushion cactus
ThingDef.description: A short cactus. It is so named because it resembles a pincushion.

ThingDef.label: low shrubs
ThingDef.description: Various low broadleaf shrubs. These grow in clusters and slow down movement.

ThingDef.label: alocasia
ThingDef.description: A tropical plant. Its extremely broad leaves are a commonly-recognized signifier of tropical forests.

ThingDef.label: clivia
ThingDef.description: An unusual plant with tall, pretty flowers. Some call it the 'bush lily'.

ThingDef.label: giant rafflesia
ThingDef.description: A rare, giant flower which can be found deep in steaming jungles. You would think a giant flower would be beautiful, but this one looks and smells like rotting flesh.

ThingDef.label: chokevine
ThingDef.description: Tangled masses of cord-like, spiky vines which coil in great masses along the ground. Chokevine greatky slows down anyone who moves over it. Multiple tribes have independently generated stories of chokevine strangling children to death in the night, as a way to scare kids into coming home before dark.

ThingDef.label: glowstool
ThingDef.description: A small brown mushroom typically found in caves. It smells like an old, dirty rag pulled from the stomach of a rotting muffalo - but it tastes surprisingly good when cooked. Dies when exposed to light.

ThingDef.label: agarilux
ThingDef.description: An enormous purple mushroom. Its size and glowing protrusions make this fungus beautiful to look at. It dies when exposed to light.

ThingDef.label: bonsai cocoa tree
ThingDef.description: A tropical tree that produces chocolate, genetically engineered to sweeten its own product, and survive in slightly less-warm climates.

ThingDef.label: bonsai oak tree
ThingDef.description: A hardwood tree. Oaks take a long time to grow, but their wood is so strong that 'oak' is used as a metaphor for strength across many cultures.

ThingDef.label: bonsai poplar tree
ThingDef.description: A softwood tree that grows very fast. Unfortunately, its wood is weak and so it yields less useful material than hardwood trees.

ThingDef.label: bonsai pine tree
ThingDef.description: A large conifer covered with prickly pine cones. It grows in a distinctive conical shape.

ThingDef.label: bonsai birch tree
ThingDef.description: A temperate-biome tree known for its thin, white, paper-like bark.

ThingDef.label: saguaro cactus
ThingDef.description: A large cactus native to arid Earth environments. Though it is not a tree, it yields a small amount of fibrous material that can be used like wood.

ThingDef.label: bonsai drago tree
ThingDef.description: A hardy desert tree topped with thick, pointed leaves.

ThingDef.label: bonsai teak tree
ThingDef.description: An exceptionally strong hardwood tree that grows in warm climates. Because teak wood is so durable and water-resistant, it was used to form the keel of wooden sailing ships in ancient times.

ThingDef.label: bonsai cecropia tree
ThingDef.description: One of the most common rainforest trees. Cecropia grows very fast, but yields little usable wood.

ThingDef.label: bonsai palm tree
ThingDef.description: A tropical tree with a tall, naked trunk topped by a cluster of very broad leaves. Unfortunately, this variety doesn't produce any edible coconuts.

ThingDef.label: bonsai bamboo tree
ThingDef.description: A fast-growing tree-like plant that grows in dense groves. Bamboo can be harvested for a wood-like material. The plant itself is not beautiful.

ThingDef.label: bonsai willow tree
ThingDef.description: One of the fastest growing shade trees, willows provide a beautiful, leafy canopy. It doesn't yield much usable wood.

ThingDef.label: bonsai cypress tree
ThingDef.description: A tall coniferous tree often found in swamps. Despite its slow growth, planting these trees can be profitable as a low-effort, long-term investment because they yield so much usable wood.

ThingDef.label: bonsai maple tree
ThingDef.description: A common medium-sized tree, easily identifiable by its distinct three-pointed leaf.

ThingDef.label: ambrosia bush
ThingDef.description: A rare wild bush which yields the ambrosia fruit. Ambrosia fruit is delicious and produces a drug-like mood boost. Ambrosia cannot be farmed, which makes wild ambrosia groves very valuable.\n\nIts rarity, beauty, and desirability are why ambrosia was named after the food of the ancient Greek gods.
